summary: This paper introduces a new dataset and approach for generating clarification questions to address ambiguity in questions. The paper demonstrates the stability of the proposed approach through detailed analysis, but the evaluation lacks sufficient statistical rigor and clarity. The paper would benefit from improved clarity, more comprehensive statistical analysis, and a discussion of potential societal impacts.

strengths.text: The paper provides a detailed description of the human preference test setup, including worker restrictions and quality control measures.
The paper introduces a new dataset for research in this area.
The authors provide a detailed analysis of test results, showing the stability of CQ across different interpretations (Figure 9).
Figure 2 provides a clear overview of the proposed approach with well-labeled blocks.
The paper is generally well organized with clear sectioning.
The introduction clearly explains the problem of ambiguous questions and motivates the proposed clarification question approach (Section 1).
Table 2 provides clear examples of manual revisions, aiding in understanding the process, and Table 10 provides a clear overview of the most frequent categories.
The paper clearly distinguishes contributions and method differences from a closely related approach [2].

weaknesses.text: The paper does not provide sufficient information on the statistical analysis performed on the human preference data.
The paper overclaims the performance of the generated clarification questions due to various factors.
The paper lacks crucial information regarding the environment used for the human preference test (Section C.1) and the seeds used for random selection of examples or batch creation.
Dataset license and usage restrictions are not stated.
Figure 3 lacks clear axis labels and units, making it difficult to interpret the results.
The definition of 'clarification question' (CQ) could be more precise, and the paper lacks a clear notation table.
Several tables lack crucial statistical information such as standard deviations, confidence intervals, or p-values, making it difficult to assess the significance of the results.
The paper lacks a discussion of potential misuse or failure modes.
The paper is missing a head-to-head comparison with a top cited baseline.

suggestions.text: Include a discussion of inter-annotator agreement and its impact on the results (Section C.1).
Further research is needed to improve evaluation methods for clarification question generation tasks (Conclusion section).
Provide the code used for the experiment, including the MTurk setup and data processing scripts, and specify the random seeds used for example selection and batch creation (Section C.1).
Document the environment used for the human preference test, including the MTurk platform and any relevant libraries (Section C.1).
Add explicit license and consent statements for datasets used.
In Figure 3, add labels to the axes to clarify what is being measured and the units used. Consider adding a legend if different colors are used.
Provide a concise definition of 'clarification question' early in the introduction and include a notation table (or list of abbreviations) in the appendix or after the introduction.

Include standard deviations or confidence intervals to indicate the variability of the results. Add p-values to indicate statistical significance of performance differences. Clearly define all acronyms and abbreviations used in table headers and captions. Provide more context for the metrics used, such as the number of samples or trials (Tables 1-9).
Add a Broader Impact section with mitigation strategies (Conclusion).
Add ablation isolating the delta vs. cited method [1] (what the new module adds) (Sec 4.1).
